title: Lem/Leme
common:
André L. FR. Clayes research suggests Lem Gilles as the patriarch of the family in Bugres (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 59).

Luiz G. Silva Leme propose that the name origin has relationship with "argila ou grêda" (Silva Leme, Luiz G., Vol. II, pp. 179), but André L. FR. Clayes' research suggests that the family name as first name of Willem, or it is a contraction (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 6-7).

In this project we only call attention to some contradictions, for more knowledge about the family, it is suggested to study Margarida O. R. Paes Leme (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008 ; Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2016 ; Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2019)), André L. FR. Clayes (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012), Philippe Garnier (Garnier, Philippe, 2006), Monsenhor Antonio Paes Cintra (Cintra, Antonio P, Monsenhor, 1944), and Manuel Valente Barbas (Barbas, Manoel V, 1996).

families.name: Leme
history: The Leme's family begins in Portugal with business and Lem Maerten I's migration (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 44-49 ; Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 60-62).

people.name: Lem Maerten I
history: Portuguese authors normally translate his name (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 44-49 ; de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 3), but this project names him as he was in Bugres.

It is also necessary to clarify a marriage that did not happen. According to André L. FR. Clayes, the fact that authors do not know Dutch language, Lem Maerten I's language, conduct them to affirm that he also had a marriage in Flanders, but the person that had marriage was his homonymous son (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61).
In the Armeiro Mor's book, that has a beautiful coat of arms, but it does not have its documentation, exposes the Lem Maerten I's arms (do Cró, João , 1509, fl. 110 (img. 235)).

The Afonso V's chancellery informs that Lem Maerten I's authorized his Jewish creditors to be sent to Christianity justice (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 48 ; Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 63v (img. 98)).
One of his sons, Rui Leme, appears as a witness in treaty of Tordesillas (Tratado de Tordesillas (Folio 6r)).

marriages.name: Joana Barroso
history: According to André L. FR. Clayes (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61-62, 66, 71). Emanuel Soeiro (Sueyro, Emanuel, pp. 494) and Henrique H. de Noronha (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 41) also cite this marriage.

This marriage is considered as hypothetical, because there is a legitimation letter of a Martim Leme with his brothers and sisters. He could be a half-brother, or he was legitimated independent of to be a different mother, of finally this marriage did not happen.

marriages.name: Leonor Rodrigues
history: She did not have marriage with Lem Maerten I (Arquivo Municipal de Lisboa, doc. 24 PT/AMLSB/CMLSBAH/ADM/002/0284/0022), but she was mother (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 47-48) of 7 of his legitimated children (Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 66v-67 (img. 104)).

marriages.name: Van Nieuwenhove Adrienne
history: She did not have marriage with Lem Maerten I, instead, she had marriage with Lem Maerten II (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61, 67, 71, 72).
She could be the person cited by Luiz G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., Vol. II, pp. 179-180).

children.name: Martim Leme
history: Probably the unique son of the first marriage (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61-62, 66, 71). The Emanuel Sueyro's propose about a marriage with a Barroso helps to understanding the confusion cited by André L. FR. Clayes (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61).
Legitimaed by his father (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 47 ; Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 67 (img. 104)).
He is treated as a hypothetical son, because we have doubts about his mother.

children.name: Antonio Leme
history: Legitimated by his father (Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 67 (img. 104)).

children.name: Rui Leme
history: Legitimated by his father (Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 8, fl. 67 (img. 104)).

people.name: Rui Leme
history: There is no data linked to him about any marriage or children (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 118-119).
He received the title of knight during Dom Manuel I's reign (Chancelaria Régia, Manuel I, Livro 28, fl. 110 (img. 180)).
Among his political actions, it is necessary to highlight the fact that he was a witness in Treaty of Tordesillas (Tratado de Tordesillas (Folio 6r)).

people.name: Martim Leme
history: The fact that authors do not know Dutch language conduct them to do mistakes with his father's history (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61). There is also issues to define his mother (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61 ; Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 47).
His activities in Flanders were organized through documentation by André L. FR. Clayes (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 15, 26, 31, 33, 57 ).

marriages.name: Van Nieuwenhove Adrienne
history: She did not have marriage with Len Maerten I, as it was explained above (Clayes, André L. FR, 2012, pp. 61, 67, 71, 72)

people.name: Antonio Leme
history: He lived during the 15th century, but only during the 20th century we started to understand more about him when Luiz P. M. de Castro published his work (de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938).

Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme, following to Montarroyo, says correctly that he is a son of Lem Maerten I and Leonor Rodrigues, but he did not inform his wife's name (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Vol. III, pp.1-2,8-9). Continuing his text, he wrote that he had a homonymous grandson that "Casou com Catharina de Barros ... filha de Pedro Gonçalves da Camara e de sua mulher Isabel de Barros.", and centuries after this, Luiz G. Silva Leme (Silva Leme, Luiz G., Vol. II, pp. 180-182) accepted the idea, but this sentence needs a deep study:
  • Montarroyo had a confusion, because grandson and grandfather are the same person (de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 5-7).
  • The marriage with a descendant of Pedro Gonçalves da Câmara did not happen. Using Henrique H. Noronha's work (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 42 ; de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 96) that cites his father-in-law testament, Luiz P. M. de Castro corrected the mistake.
  • Noronha brought us the mistake with homonymous, but he also had his own mistakes with Antonio Leme's ancestors as Philippe Garnier shows (Garnier, Philippe, 2006).

He also received an arm coat like his father (Chancelaria Régia, Afonso V, Livro 21, fl. 90 (img. 173)), that was copied in different papers (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 40 ; de Castro, Luiz P. M., 1938, pp. 15,16 ; Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2008, pp. 68).

It is possible that his brother, Rui Leme, was not the unique family member to have a relationship with the "discover" of Abya Yala/América, because as a Chronicle informs, he had a meeting with Columbus talking about supposed three islands that he observed in a navigation (de Armas, Antonio Romeu, 1971, pp. 545, 547-548).

The last mistake that is necessary to highlight has the relationship with his son Antão Leme, that is not mentioned by Henrique H. de Noronha (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 42 ; de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 9-10). This mistake was corrected with a document of his grandson (de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 16-17).

marriages.name: Not Known
history: According to nobiliarchy (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 42 ; Silva Leme, Luiz G., Vol. II, pp. 180-182 ; Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Vol. III, pp.8-9).

marriages.name: Catharina de Barros
history: According to her dowry documentation (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2019, 79, 87-88). It is also necessary to highlight that since Henrique H. de Noronha's work (de Noronha, Henrique H., 1745, fl. 42) were published, we understand that she is a daughter of Pedro Gonçalves da Clara and Isabel de Barros (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2019, 79). The confusion about Catharina de Barros parents is also explained by Monsenhor Antonio Paes Cintra (Cintra, Antonio P, Monsenhor, 1944, pp. 21 - 26).

children.name: Antão Leme
history: According to his son document (Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, 2010, pp. 56-57 ; de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 16-17).

people.name: Antão Leme
history: Margarida O. R. Paes Leme's work published in ASBRAP (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2016) has everything necessary to understand him, so we suggest studying it.

marriages.name: Not Known
history: There is not any document citing her.

children.name: Pero Leme
history: According to his nobility justification document (Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, 2010, pp. 56-57 ; de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 16-17)

people.name: Pero Leme
history: He names himself as Pero and not Pedro in his inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 1, pp. 26), so we will work with his words.

Frei Gaspar Madre de Deus' work (Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, 2010, pp. 55-58) and Margarida O. R. Paes Leme's works (Paes Leme, Margarida O. R., 2016) clarify subjects about his life, but there are texts inside them that need to be highlighted.

His inventory informs two marriages with Luzia Fernandes and Gracia Rodrigues respectively (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 1, pp. 31, 41), despite that a third marriage was created as explained by Luiz P. M. de Castro (de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 10-14). On this page, it is given links for documentation used by Luiz P. M. de Castro:
  • Luiz P. M. de Castro copied a text from Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme's work (de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938, pp. 11 ) that is on a different page in the edition we have access (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Vol. III, pp. 11).
  • Pero Leme's inventory does not talk about a wife named Isabel Paes, but it cites Luzia Fernandes and Gracia Rodrigues (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 1, pp. 25-64). It also does not have information about a son named Fernão Dias Paes.
  • Fernão Dias Paes' wife, Lucrécia Leme, cites her brother, Braz Esteves, in her inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 14, pp. 316). In her mother, Leonor Leme, inventory it is given the confirmation that Leonor Leme and Braz Esteves are brothers, and a son-in-law of her, Fernão Dias, also confirms a document (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 9, pp. 6-8).
  • Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme letter to Frei Gaspar Madre de Deus (Publicação official de documentos interessantes para a historia e costumes de São Paulo ... Vol. 4, 1895, pp. 21-24 ; de Castro, Luiz P. M., 1938, pp. 18-19) shows that Fernão Dias Paes' son treats Pero Leme as a "great-grandfather" and not as a "grandfather".
  • Pedro Dias Paes (Leme) nobility justification (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 27, pp. 219-263), that probably made all the confusion about a third marriage, hides Lucrécia Leme creating a fake patrilineal lineage that reaches Pero Leme.

The supposed marriage with Isabel Paes (Silva Leme, Luiz G., Vol. II, pp. 442), conducted José Gonçalves Salvador to suspect that Fernão Dias Paes, his supposed son, was a Jewish person because he was named a "Jewish dog" during a discussion in front of a church, but the rival asked for forgiveness after the event (Salvador, José G., 1969, pp. 135), in the same book, when he describes analogous defamation, used by Camargo's family, he explains that to call a person Jewish was common "Calúnia da oposição? Talvez. Era uma forma de vingança comum naqueles dias" (Salvador, José G., 1969, pp. 10). The missing data that could prove that families Leme or Dias have Jewish ancestors, changes José G. Salvador initial position years later when he writes: "Fernão Dias Paes Leme, o das esmeraldas, foi casado com uma senhora da estirpe cristã-nova" (Salvador, José G., 1976, pp. 142), but this sentence has another mistake, so we invite the reader to study the families Betim (Betim, History Tracers) , Fernandes (Fernandes, History Tracers) and Rodrigues (Rodrigues, History Tracers) on this project to understand the reason Maria Betim, Fernão Dias Paes (Leme)'s wife, is not Jewish.

marriages.name: Luzia Fernandes
history: According to Pero Leme's inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 1, pp. 31).

marriages.name: Gracia Rodrigues
history: According to inventories of Pero Leme's and Gracia Rodrigues (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 1, pp. 31, 41).

marriages.name: Isabel Paes
history: According to nobility justification (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 27, pp. 219-263) that forces an unreal patrilineal lineage (de Castro, Luiz P. M., 1938), but there is a small probably this could happen according documentation and time (Barbas, Manoel V, 1996, pp. 81-82).

children.name: Leonor Leme
history: De acordo com palavras de seu pai, na casa de seu esposo (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 1, pp. 25, 31).

people.name: Leonor Leme
history: When she was 80 years old, she was witness in the canonization of Saint José de Anchieta, this document also says she was born in Óbidos, Portugal (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 25). She passed away in the year 1633 (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 9, pp. 7).

Fray Gaspar Madre de Deus talks about the time she arrived in Brazil and her descendants (Madre de Deus, Gaspar, Frei, 2010, pp. 51-52), while Manuel Valente Barbas extends our knowledge (Barbas, Manoel V, 1996, pp. 74-77, 81-83), so it is suggested to study his work.

marriages.name: Bráz Esteves
history: According to her own words (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 9, pp. 7) and her sons' words during the canonization of Saint José de Anchieta (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 22, 24, 31).

children.name: Lucrécia Leme
history: According to her mother's inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 9, pp. 6).

people.name: Lucrécia Leme
history: It is suggested for the reader to take a look at the text about her grandfather, Pero Leme, because it is explained there the confusion made about a marriage with a hypothetical uncle. It is also explained that this hypothetical relationship was made to create a patrilineal lineage.
She wrote a testament in the year 1645. The document informs also that she is mother of 15 people from a unique marriage(Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 14, pp. 313 - 343).

marriages.name: Fernão Dias (Paes)
history: According to her inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 14, pp. 316) and also her husband's inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 1, pp. 398).

This marriage is also confirmed in a Familiar of Holy Office documentation of her descendant (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62 ), and a de genere documentation of Priest João Leite da Silva, her grandson (História da Família, 2014, img. 49).

children.name: Pedro Dias (Paes)
history: According to his mother's inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 14, pp. 314) and also his father's inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 1, pp. 401).

This relationship is also confirmed in a Familiar of Holy Office documentation of his descendant (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62 ), and a de genere documentation of Priest João Leite da Silva, his son (História da Família, 2014, img. 49).

people.name: Pedro Dias (Paes)
history: When Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme talks about him, it is informed that "ocupou os cargos da república muitas vezes" (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Vol. III, pp.57). It is possible to find different citations to Pedro Dias, that it is understanding to be him, in São Paulo Town Hall documentation (Atas de São Paulo, Volume II).
He passed away in the year 1633 (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Vol. III, pp.57), during the same year it was written his inventory(Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 9, pp. 53 - 72).

The next subject will be better exposed when we work with his wife's family, but it is necessary to append some notes here about his father-in-law, Paschoal Leite (Furtado). According to Pedro T. de A. Paes Leme, Paschoal Leite Furtado, would be from a nobles' family, but witnesses during the canonization of Saint José de Anchieta (Viotti, Hélio A., 1996, 22, 30, 31) show he has Indigenous ancestors (Projeto Compartilhar, Izabel do Prado). He was not the unique indigenous to reach this family. The genetic mapping made in research in progress shows that Maria de Faria, a great-grandmother of Maria Leite da Silva, is also an Indigenous (Sillos, Luiz, 2023, t. 00:46:27), and as we are talking about a matrilineal lineage, this implies that her children had an Indigenous mitochondrial DNA. This is an important fact, because around 140 years before, this family was witness in Treaty of Tordesillas that allowed Abya Ayla/America colonization, and now a descendant was having marriage with a peson that has different Indigenous ancestors.

marriages.name: Maria Leite da Silva
history: This relationship is cited in her husband's inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 9, pp. 55) and her own inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 17, pp. 418).

The marriage is also cited in a Familiar of Holy Office documentation of a descendant (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62 ), and a de genere documentation of Priest João Leite da Silva, her son (História da Família, 2014, img. 49).

children.name: Fernão Dias Paes
history: He is cited in his father's inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 9, pp. 56) and his mother's inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 17, pp. 416).
The marriage is also cited in a Familiar of Holy Office documentation of a descendant (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62 ).
In a research not finalized, it was discovered that her mitochondrial haplogroup is A2 (Sillos, Luiz, 2023, t. 00:46:27).

children.name: João Leite da Silva
history: He is cited in his father's inventory when he was one year old (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 9, pp. 56) and his mother's inventory where he was already a Priest (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 17, pp. 416).
This relationship is confirmed in his de genere (História da Família, 2014, img. 49).
In a research not finalized, it was discovered that her mitochondrial haplogroup is A2 (Sillos, Luiz, 2023, t. 00:46:27).

people.name: João Leite da Silva
history: The priest João Leite da Silva has his trial showing he was a "clean blood" added to the nobility justification of Pedro Dias Paes (Leme), a descendant of his brother (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 27, pp. 223 - 251 ),

A possible "mistake" suggests that he, or a supposed homonymous, had a marriage with his mother in a genealogical tree exposed in Holy Office Familiar documentation (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62).

people.name: Fernão Dias Paes
history:
His actions in different colonial areas helped authors to make different books about him, but some of them have mistakes. Diogo Luiz de A. P. de Vasconcellos (de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P., 1904, pp. 31 - 44) shows mistakes in Pedro de A. T. Paes Leme's work (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Vol. III, pp. 61 - 78), but his work is not perfect either. To help the reader to identify them, they are listed below:
  • Fernão Dias Paes' age is the first issue demonstrated by Diogo Luiz de A. P. de Vasconcellos, he shows that is not possible to consider he was older than 80 during some expeditions (de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P., 1904, pp. 31, 34). It is possible to confirm this by reading his father's inventory that informs us he was 25 years old in 1633 (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 9, pp. 56), in consequence of this, when he passed away in the year 1681 (de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P., 1904, pp. 42-43), he would be 73 years old.
  • Pedro Taques transcribes a document talking about "minas de prata e esmeralda" [silver and emeralds mines] (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Vol. III, pp. 66 - 67) written before the expedition of the year 1673. Diogo Luiz de A. P. de Vasconcellos disagree (de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P., 1904, pp. 34) citing another letter from infant D. Pedro written in November, 30th 1674 (Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Vol. III, pp. 62), showing te expedition happened in 1674.
  • Diogo Luiz de A. P. de Vasconcellos cites Maria Betim as a descendant of Maria Alvares Cabral, a hypothetical sister of Pedro Alvares Cabral (de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P., 1904, pp. 36). He does not say the primary source used to get the information, so it is not possible to confirm this part of his work directly. But, research made by the Viscount of Sanches Baéna shows this information is not correct (Sanches Baena, Visconde de, 1897, pp. 13 - 21).

According to previous information about his maternal grandparents, Fernão Dias Paes has Indigenous DNA mitochondrial, and his maternal grandfather also was an indigenous person. Research in progress shows that his wife has mitochondrial haplogroup C1b (subgroup) (Sillos, Luiz, 2023, t. 01:07:10), so his children also have an Indigenous mitochondrial DNA. These facts were not a barrier to take some actions against indigenous:
  • Diogo Luiz de A. P. de Vasconcellos cites him with "milhares de escravos, além de muitas aldeias de indíos" [thousands of slaves, and many indigenous tribes] (de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P., 1904, pp. 31 - 44).
  • He conquered three, Indigenous "kingdoms" that were hostile during his life, and he conducted more than 5000 Indigenous to São Paulo. The chronists say that his intention was to move them for priests to teach them as Christians (de Vasconcellos, Diogo Luiz de A. P., 1904, pp. 32 - 33 ; Paes Leme, Pedro T. de A., 1976, Vol. III, pp. 63 - 65).
The original idea of the 1674 expedition was to find emeralds, but they found tourmaline (Rodrigues, André F., 2003).

Fernão Dias Paes actions during the civil war begins sending Jesuits out of the city, but later he would help to bring them back (Taunay, Afonso de E., 1927, 28-29, 73-74). His actions together Pires' family brought to him a defamation by Camargo's family, that said he was Jewish, because he had a marriage with a Fernandes, but this defamation was false (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 43).

marriages.name: Maria Garcia
history: According to her son's baptism (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 159).

children.name: Garcia Roiz Paes
history: According to his baptism (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 159).

people.name: Garcia Roiz Paes
history:
Garcia Roiz Paes' history is an example of how war effects and defamation never end, independent of defamator asks for forgiven (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 5, 42, 48, 95, 111). It is necessary to begin with defamation to understand the whole scenario:

  • The defamation began with his great-great-uncle during the war (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 42, 44, 47 - 49, 66, 94).
  • They continue with a grandmother, a niece of André Fernandes (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 24, 28, 30, 45, 68 - 69, 71, 94, 110). And they also affected Garcia Roiz Velho, Maria Betim's husband, because he helped Pires' family. Firstly it was used the marriage, and after this, it was invented that he did not become a Priest to be a Jewish person. In reality, he did not become a Priest, because he killed people and had a marriage (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 28 - 29, 67 - 68 ).
  • His father was also a Pires allied, so we have a third generation receiving defamation (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 4, 43).

Three consecutive generations with defamation had direct result on him. The remaining texts about his diligence informs us that infamado de Cristão Novo por parte de sua avó materna por fama constante (Torre do Tombo, Mesa da Consciência e Ordens, Habilitações para a Ordem de Cristo, Letra G, mç. 6, n.º 66; Bogaciovas, Marcelo M. A, 2015, pp. 279-280). Would a partial primary source to be enough to define some person? Is there more data available? These additional questions bring necessity to use the scientific method:

  • The scientific method starts with the hypotheses:
    • HYPOTHESIS 1: According to it, the fact that there was a note about his grandmother having a "fame" of being Jewish it is enough to define her history.
    • HYPOTHESIS 2: A mention of "fame" is not enough to define anything. The whole historical context and available documentation should be studied, and only after this, it is possible to arrive at a conclusion.
  • After having the hypotheses, it is necessary to look for primary sources that allow to confirm them::
    • HYPOTHESIS 1: It only accepts a partial document saying the family Betim had "a constant fame" of New Christian (Torre do Tombo, Mesa da Consciência e Ordens, Habilitações para a Ordem de Cristo, Letra G, mç. 6, n.º 66). They can not accept other documents (History Tracers, 2003, Manuel Fernandes Ramos ) where the fame is also cited, because they are complete document showing the fame is false.
    • HYPOTHESIS 2 the explanation about the "constant fame" can be found in defamation for three consecutive generations:
      • The "prove" used to create the fame that Fernandes were Jewish is a poem, for more details, take a look at what was written for Fernandes' family (History Tracers, 2003, Manuel Fernandes Ramos ; History Tracers, 2003, André Fernandes ).
      • Maria Betim was a niece of André Fernandes, and this is the main reason she also received defamation. This relationship also brought defamation against her husband (History Tracers, 2003, Maria Betim).
      • Finally, his father also received defamation, because he married a person from Fernandes' family (History Tracers, 2003, Fernão Dias Paes).
      • The witnesses are not the unique source to prove Garcia Roiz Paes is not a Jewish person, there are also documentations proving his ancestors were Christian: his baptism (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 159), his mother's baptism (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 25, 160) and a de genere of his son, Ignácio Dias (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 7, 39 42 - 44, 51, 88, 121).
  • The THEORY is made using primary sources and comparing them with the hypotheses:
    • The HYPOTHESIS 1 is accepted mainly by people defending the marranism idea, but to accept it means to ignore not only the witnesses, but all available documentation, the war scenario, and the fact that he defamator asked for forgiveness. Another fact always ignored by people defending the HYPOTHESIS 1 is the way that the Portuguese inquisition worked, it is suggested for the reader, to understand better, the study of Antonio J. Saraiva's work (Saraiva, Antonio José, 1969). A HYPOTHESIS 2 is preferred, because it does not ignore any information. This understanding allows it to say that Garcia Roiz Paes does not have any Jewish ancestors known nowadays. Q.E.D. (Util new documents appear that can change current understanding, because science always advances with data.).

The " Guarda Mor Geral das Minas de Ouro", Garcia Roiz Paes, passed away on March 07th, 1730 (Endangered Archives Programme, img. 60).

people.name: Pedro Dias Paes (Leme)
history:
The Familiar of Holy Office documentations of Pedro Dias Paes (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476) and his cousin Domingos Jorge da Silva (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 122 ; Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Oficio, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Domingos, mç. 21, doc. 419) show that defamation was a weapon used during the civil war by Camargo's family. The diligence was already used with different ancestors, so here it is only mapped and cited some texts:

  • In the beginning of the document it is resumed how families Fernandes, Leme, Paes, Garcia Velho, e Tavares 'became' Jewish (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 3 - 8).
  • The defamation details are cited by different witnesses, and we would like to highlight Priest Fray Francisco de S. José and Joseph Mascarenhas, a Jesuit (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 9 - 158).
  • The Priest Fray Francisco de S. José informs "ouvira dizer que um Francisco de Camargo, por alcunha o Tigre, homem conhecidamente de má lingoa, dissera em certa occasião, que havia de ir pôr ... judeo de André Fernandes ascendente de Garcia Roiz Paes" (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 42).
  • Joseph Mascarenhas does not allow doubts when talking about Pedro Dias Paes: "Digo e afirmo que o Dor Pº Dias Paes, quer por parte paterna, quer por parte materna puro, e de limpo sangue sem raça alguma de Judeu, Mouro, Mouriço, ou outra qualquer nação infecta". No mesmo parágrafo, complementa "Bem he verdade que nos annos antigos houve uma fama não constante, nem comũa por falta de fundamentos, mais que do ódio" (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 128 - 129).
  • Joseph Masracarenhas also added:
    • "a descendência dos Fernandes entraram muitos nas ordens Terceiras, e na irmandade da Misericórdia onde se apuram p vas gerações a limpeza destes odernarao se de sacerdotes depois da infâmia, o padre António Soares, filho de António Francisco de Abreo, bisneto por parte paterna de Baltazar Fernandes, irmão do Capitão André Fernandes, o P Frei Franco Bicudo, religioso de Nosssa Senhora do Carmo Conven.. de São Paulo, filho de Bar de Godoi Bicudo, bisneto por parte materna de Baltazar Fernandes, irmão do Cap. André Fernandes, o padre Bªr de Godoy Bicudo, filho do capitão Bernardo de Campos Bicudo terceiro neto por parte materna do .. Bar Fernades. O Pe Victorino de Borba Leite, filho do tenente general Mel de Borba Gato de huma irmã do Capm Guarda mor Garcia Roiz Paes"
    (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 49 ).
  • Documents proofing the facts are added (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 159 - 160).
  • After Pedro Dias Paes' trial ends, it is presented his wife's trial, Francisca Joaquina Forjas Pereira (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 160 - 231 ).

Another document needs to be studied, his nobility justification. One of the issues present in this document was already presented, the supposed patrilineal lineage that reaches Pedro Leme (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 27, pp. 219 - 220), that is not confirmed by any primary source (de Castro, Luiz P. M. , 1938). The second "issue" probably cannot be classified like this. The surname utilization did not have a well-defined pattern during centuries (Monteiro, Nuno G., 2008 ; Gonçalves, Iria.), and Pedro Dias Paes (Leme)'s documentation shows this:

  • In his diligence for Holy Office Familiar, he is named as Pedro Dias Paes many times (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 1, 15, 47, 50, 82, 84, 134, 136, 142, 199, 203, 210, 231 ), but he is also named as Pedro Dias Paes Leme (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62, 66). His nobility justification by Leme's family, we have him always named as Pedro Dias Paes Leme (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 27, pp. 219 - 220, 222, 256 - 260 ).
  • When we take a look at his great-grandfather, Pedro Dias, citations, it is observed that he is named as Pedro Dias in his mother's Lucrécia Leme inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 14, pp. 314). The same pattern is also observed in his inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 9, pp. 55) and in his wife's inventory (Inventários e Testamentos, 1921, Volume 17, pp. 418). On the other hand, João Leite da Silva, his son, has documentation names him as Pedro Dias Leme (Inventários e Testamentos, 1920, Volume 27, pp. 223 - 251 ), finally in the diligence he is named as Pedro Dias Paes (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício: Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Pedro, mç. 25, doc. 476, img. 62, 82, 137, 158 ).

children.name: Garcia Roiz Paes Leme

people.name: Garcia Roiz Paes Leme
history:
Pedro Dias Paes (Leme) had a deep investigation about their ancestors, so Garcia Roiz Paes Leme's diligence was simpler. It is shown some details below:
  • There was not any fame to be Jewish after his uncle's diligence explains everything (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Garcia, mç. 1, doc. 7, img. 3).
  • When he talks about his ancestors, there is a highlight for the fact that an uncle, Pedro Dias Paes Leme, and a cousin, Roberto Car Ribeiro, were Familiar of Holy Office (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Garcia, mç. 1, doc. 7, img. 5-6 ).
  • In the sequence, there are questions and witnesses answering (Torre do Tombo, Tribunal do Santo Ofício, Conselho Geral, Habilitações, Garcia, mç. 1, doc. 7, img. 7 - 65 ).
